awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Extreme-scale Ready High-order Methods for Astrophysical and Laboratory Turbulence
awd_abstract_narration:
Astrophysical phenomena inherently involve multi-physics and multi-scales that are nonlinearly coupled.  The mathematical accuracy and efficiency of the computational tools used to test theoretical models hugely impact the scientific outcomes.  The astrophysics community has thus long focused on developing computationally accurate numerical algorithms that give improved solution accuracy, stability, and efficiency.  This project tackles the challenge of developing new approaches to address these problems, and incorporating these methods in the FLASH community code in order to reach a large audience in the astrophysics community.  The work lies at the nexus of applied and computational mathematics, statistical Gaussian Process (GP) data predictions, and astrophysics.  Involvement in NSF-supported outreach will help to educate under-represented community college students in computational astrophysics.  Training young scientists in astrophysical and laboratory turbulence using validated simulations also helps to meet a critical national need.

This study will develop high-order accurate, novel algorithms with only modest complexity, using a new high-order GP spatial reconstruction approach and a novel single-step high-order temporal integration method.  This powerful predictive tool will run on massively parallel high-performance architectures.  The study involves, firstly, using the novel GP approach to overcome the second-order bottleneck in most finite-volume shock-capturing astrophysics codes.  The GP algorithms provide a simple mathematical framework for computing highly accurate volume-averaged versus pointwise quantities, and multidimensional spatial reconstructions.  The second important development is an efficient high-order temporal integration method in adaptive mesh refinement grid configurations.  This requires a single-step time update at a single quadrature point per cell face, which will provide the most efficient algorithmic framework in extreme-scale parallel simulations.  Finally, comparing simulation results based on solution accuracy, errors, and computational performance for key astrophysical flow problems, including astrophysical and laboratory turbulence, will demonstrate the impact and benefit of these advances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past three years, our research team at Michigan State University has embarked on an effort to advance astrophysical simulations. Funded by the National Science Foundation, our project aimed to significantly enhance the accuracy and performance of simulations of astrophysical turbulence. Through the development of innovative numerical schemes and data emulation techniques, we've made major progress in modeling the cosmos.

Achievements Overview:

Year 1: Foundations of Innovation Our initial year was dedicated to refining the Gaussian process (GP) interpolation schemes. A major breakthrough was establishing a connection with radial basis interpolation, allowing us to analytically determine optimal hyperparameters for GP kernels. This optimization led to significantly improved convergence rates, setting a strong foundation for the subsequent advancements in our project.

Year 2: Enhancing Spark and Embracing GPUs Despite the global challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, our second year marked notable enhancements to our Spark solver, a high-order magnetohydrodynamics solver within the FLASH framework. We extended Spark to fifth-order accuracy and adapted it for GPU utilization, a leap forward in computational efficiency. Additionally, we developed a memory-efficient scheme for emulating tabulated data in physical simulations, overcoming significant performance hurdles.

Year 3: Exploring Turbulence with High-Order Methods The final year focused on the impact of high-order numerical schemes on simulating compressible turbulence, particularly in astrophysical flows. This exploration into driven, sub-sonic turbulent flows without magnetic fields has opened new avenues for understanding the complexities of astrophysical phenomena through simulation.

Intellectual Merit: This project has significantly advanced computational astrophysics by enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of numerical simulations. The optimization of Gaussian process (GP) interpolation schemes and the analytical determination of optimal hyperparameters for GP kernels have contributed valuable new tools and methodologies to the field. The extension of our Spark solver to fifth-order accuracy and its adaptation for GPU architectures represent crucial technological advancements, providing substantial speedups over traditional CPU-based approaches. These developments not only improve current simulation capabilities but also serve as a benchmark for future research, deepening our understanding of astrophysical phenomena and laying the groundwork for further exploration into high-order numerical schemes' effects on turbulence.

Broader Impacts: Beyond the immediate scientific community, the project's achievements in data emulation and computational efficiency have broader implications. By setting a new standard for handling large datasets in simulations, our work facilitates more accurate modeling of complex phenomena, which is essential for various applications, including climate modeling, disaster prediction, and environmental conservation. The technological advances achieved, particularly in GPU adaptation, position astrophysical simulations to leverage next-generation computing platforms, ensuring continued scientific progress. Moreover, the project's outcomes underscore the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration and computational literacy, contributing to the training and development of future scientists and engineers. Our heartfelt gratitude extends to the National Science Foundation, whose support has been pivotal, and to our dedicated team, whose collective effort and commitment have driven this project's success.
